title: 113_s274
content: The Act may be cited as the "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act". It includes definitions for various terms. The Act, also known as the "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act", defines terms such as elementary school, local educational agency, secondary school, and State educational agency according to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It also defines "programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education" as initiatives that enhance students' ability to choose healthy foods, consider various influences on healthy eating, provide education for making healthy choices as adults, and utilize scientifically sound nutritional materials and methods. The Act, also known as the "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act", emphasizes the importance of using scientifically sound and developmentally appropriate methods, along with nutritional materials supported by the most recent Dietary Guidelines for Americans. It also includes professional development programs for teachers, school staff, and food service workers to promote healthy eating and nutrition effectively in schools. Programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education are emphasized in the Act. Local educational agencies receiving assistance under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 must develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools, including integrating these programs throughout the school day and using educational materials emphasizing knowledge of healthy foods, especially fresh fruits and vegetables. Local educational agencies must promote healthy eating and nutrition education in schools by integrating programs throughout the school day. This includes emphasizing fresh fruits and vegetables, a balanced approach to healthy diet and lifestyle, integrating healthy eating with physical activity, and offering a variety of wellness activities. Schools should also periodically monitor their efforts in improving nutrition understanding among students. Agencies should consult with families, students, and school stakeholders in developing and implementing these programs. The curr_chunk focuses on developing programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education by consulting with various stakeholders, working with organizations with nutrition expertise, and collaborating with government authorities such as Team Nutrition. The education and obesity prevention grant program aims to provide technical assistance for designing programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools. This includes working with wellness councils, integrating programs with school wellness policies, and offering professional development in nutrition education to staff members. Each State educational agency must meet specific requirements when receiving assistance under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The Secretary of Education requires periodic reports on nutrition education programs in schools. An inter-agency task force will review and recommend effective nutrition education curricula for elementary and secondary schools. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
